div1.p: [Carter] describes a storm at sea through which they have sailed.

div1.head: Letter fragment from [Henry Rose Carter] to [s.n.], April 21, [19--?]
div1.p:
We could not go this morning: itthere is too
much wind, It began sunday at 1. A. M.
& was blowing a good breeze yesterday, & by
night blowing hard- last (Sunday)
night & this morning & indeed all day
it increased to a regular gale hardest
about 8 to 10 A. M.- From the East all
the time. It is a regular cyclone, with
the centre south of us & moving almost
north- so I suppose tomorrow the wind
will “haul” - i. e. came from the W. & we
will have a high tide. It was high
enough today: but not so high as I have
seen it, & everything is fast & staved down
snug, except some cord wood, which
I hope is too high to be washed away. It has
never been hurt & has been there 13 mos.
nearly, When you get this you will know
how we came out.

There is a large barque-Norwegian-loaded
with timber out side at anchor & she has
dragged about 3 1/2 to 4 miles. further than
Wood
U. S. Treasury Department.
to Morris Fontaine's. She is holding her
own now that the current, which runs
very strongly where she is, is helping her,
she is in no danger as she could drift 10 miles
or maybe 15. before she struck any
thing, only she can't be comfortable,
I fear the backing up of the gulf will
break the rest of the levels before N. O.
There has been no rain here as yet: but
we will get that just before the centre
passes & afterwards. There is less rain
here than ashore anyway

23. night Wind has hauled to S. E & stood
there for the past 3 hours i. E. we won't
get the worst of it, the centre will pass to
the west; Very high tide at noon & if the centre
passes by midnight or even 6 A. M we will
be all right & not lose a piece of plank
ship has stopped drifting
